overview.problemStatement:

If $G$ is a random graph on $2^d$ vertices, including each edge with probability $1/2$, then $G$ almost surely contains a copy of $Q_d$ (the $d$-dimensional hypercube with $2^d$ vertices and $d2^{d-1}$ many edges).



A conjecture of Erd\H{o}s and Bollob\'{a}s. Solved by Riordan \cite{Ri00}, who in fact proved this with any edge-probability $>1/4$, and proves that the number of copies of $Q_d$ is normally distributed.

See also the entry in the graphs problem collection.




References


[Ri00] Riordan, Oliver, Spanning subgraphs of random graphs. Combin. Probab. Comput. (2000), 125-148.
